result.title: Objective
result.description: To strengthen the financial sustainability of Guatemalaâ€™s Protected Areas System (SIGAP) by developing new financing vehicles within the developing ecotourism sector, while ensuring the alignment of ecotourism activities with biodiversity conservation objectives.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1.- Number of tourism routes within five pilot Western Highlands landscapes (i.e., RUMCLA - Lake Atitlan, Todos Santos Cuchumatan, Tacana Volcano, Tajumulco Volcano, and Chicabal Lagoon-Volcano) contribute to the conservation of 152,146 hectares (ha) with biodiversity of global importance.

baseline.comment: Five (5)

actual.comment:
The project is reviewing the 5 routs designed by Helvetas in oreder to ensure a good synergy with the Bussiness Plans currently under construction.
Those routes are:
- Ruta Puerta al Altiplano
- Ruta Toto-K ´iche
- Ruta Valle Central
- Ruta Boca-Costa

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2.- Total area (hectares [ha]) protected by PAs in the Western Highlands with ecotourism benefits.

baseline.comment: 7,255.4 ha (MRP Todos Santos Cuchumatan).

actual.comment:
Total hectares protected in Western Highlands with ecotourism benefits: 10,500.95
This represent an achievement of 73%
Notice that from that total:
- 9,317.74 are part of the 7 pilot areas of the project
- 2,183.21 are other protected areas in the Western Highlands not included as pilot area.
The pilot areas with ecotourism benefits are:
- Municipal Regional Park Todos Santos Cuchumatan
- Municipal Regional Park Sibinal (Canjula, Tocapote, los Maijones and Tacana)
- Permanent Ban Area Volcan Chicabal
- Corazon del Bosque
The project does not directly collaborate with the administrators of areas not included in the group of 7 pilot areas. However it fosters tourism development at regional level through caring out activities of promotion and strengthening CONAP Offices' capacities. These actions positively boost income generation from tourism, not only the 7 pilot areas, but at regional level. Due to the characteristics and location of the pilot areas, a regional strategy is crucial. The pilot areas must be linked to other tourism destinations and attractions. Examples of how the project promotes this strategy are a) the design of tourism routes and b) a press tour which promoted protected areas in the region of San Marcos.
The 2,183.21 hectares not included in the project correspond to the following protected areas:
- Vieja Catarina
- Yul Ha Saj Ha´
- El Baul
- Concepcion Chiquirichapa
- Cerro Mano de León (Cerro Sija)
- Finca Patrocinio
- Finca Comunitaria Magnolia Miramar
- Finca Comunitaria Loma Linda
- Astillero Municipal San Cristobal Cucho
IMPORTANT NOTE: The hectarage of three pilot areas have been modified during the lifetime of the project. Thus, the current size of the areas have been reduced and do not coincided with the hectares recorded in prodoc. This will affect to the "target level at the end of the project".
Following are explained the modifications:
- Volcan Chicabal: Have change from the 1,572 ha. recorder in prodoc to 496 ha. Changed through CONAP's resolution 01-08-2014 (June 2014), based on the study "LOS VOLCANES DE GUATEMALA: IDENTIFICACION Y PRIORIZACION PARA SU MANEJO DENTRO DE LA ESTRATEGIA DE DESARROLLO DEL SISTEMA NACIONAL DE AREAS PROTEGIDAS",
- Rey Tepepul: Form 3,892 ha. recorder in prodoc to 3509.91. This area has not been declared yet. The 3509.91 are the hectares proposed by the project to be register in order to resolve challenges regarding land tenure.
- Corazon del Bosque: From 35.4 ha. to 8.94 ha. This area has not been declared yet. The 8.94 are the hectares proposed by the project to be register in order to resolve challenges regarding uncertainty of land tenure.

indicator.title: Indicator 3

baseline.comment:
PA Mammals / Birds / Plants
1. 4 / 3 / 5
2. 4 / 3 / 5
3. 4 / 4 /5
4. 5 / 4 / 5
5. 3 / 2 / 5
6. 4 / 4 / 5
7. 4 / 2 / 5
Note: Five species per biological group will be used; during first 6 months of project implementation all of the species will be identified.

actual.comment:
95% Achieved
A methodology for a sustainable monitoring process was designed and was implemented in the 7 pilot areas of the project.
As part of the strategy for its sustainability, a capacity building program was also designed and implemented in the 7 pilot areas, benefiting a total of 81 people (77 men and 4 women).
Actually awaiting the final report of the activity, which will include a systematization of the experience, lessons learnt and recommendations.
Following species identified:
(G): Indicator of good environmental quality
(B): Indicator of bad environmental quality
1) Todos Santos Cuchumatan
Minor Mammals: 5; 3(G) and 2(B)
Large Mammals: 6; 1(G) and 5(B)
Birds: 11; 6(G) and 5(B)
Plants: 11; 6(G) and 5(B)
2) MRP Astillero Municipal I and II de San Pedro Sacatepequez
Minor Mammals: 7; 3(G) and 4(B)
Large Mammals: 3; 0(G) and 3(B)
Birds: 9; 4(G) and 5(B)
Plants: 12; 6(G) and 6(B)
3) MRP Astillero Municipal de San Marcos
Minor Mammals: 6; 3(G) and 3(B)
Large Mammals: 3 (B)
Birds: 16; 11(G) and 5(B)
Plants: 18; 12(G) and 6(B)
4) MRP Canjula, Tocapote, los Maijones (Sibinal)
Minor Mammals: 5; 2(G) and 3(B)
Large Mammals: 4; 1(G) and 3(B)
Birds: 16; 11(G)and 5(B)
Plants: 17; 11(G) and6(B)
5) PNR Corazon del Bosque
Minor Mammals: 3; 0(G) and 3(B)
Large Mammals: 2 (B)
Birds: 6(G) 6(B)
Plants: 6(G) 5(B)
6) MRP Rey Tepepul
Minor Mammals: 8; 2(G) and 6(B)
Large Mammals: 10 5(G) and 5(B)
Birds: 16; 11 (G) and5(B)
Plants: 18; 6(G) and 12(B)
7) PBA Volcan Chicabal
Minor Mammals:5; 2(G)and 3(B)
Large Mammals:4; 2(G) and 2(B)
Birds: 17; 11(G) and 6(B)
Plants: 15; 6(G) and 9(B)

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 4.- Change in the financial capability of the SIGAP according to that which is established in the total average score in the UNDP/GEF Financial Sustainability Scorecard.

baseline.comment:
Legal and policy framework: 39.2%
Business planning: 11.5%
Income generation tools: 24.6%
Total: 26.4%

target.comment:
Legal and policy framework: 49.2%
Business planning: 21.5%
Income generation tools: 34.6%
Total: 36.4%

actual.comment: Improvement to be assesed through the Capacity Development Tracking Tool currently being undertaken in order to be ready before the Project Midterm Review.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Strengthened legal and policy framework for implementing ecotourism as part of a strategy to engender the financial sustainability of the SIGAP.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 5.- Change in the legal and policy framework at the national level.

baseline.comment:
1) Policy for Tourism Activities in PAs
2) Co-administration policy in PAs
3) CONAP regulation for control and reinvestment of income from PAs
4) Regulation of Concession Services for Visitors in SIGAP

target.comment:
1) Policy for Tourism Activities in PAs reformed
2) Co-administration policy in PAs reformed
3) CONAP regulation for control and reinvestment of income from PAs updated
4) Regulation of Concession Services for Visitors in SIGAP updated
5) Regulatory guidelines for environmental standards and certification system for ecotourism in PAs developed.

actual.comment:
1) 100% achieved. Policy for Tourism Activities in PAs reformed.
2) 100% achieved. Co-administration Policy in PAs reformed and re-named as Policy of shared management and joint administration.
3) 80% achieved. First draft of CONAP regulation for control and reinvestment of income from PAs elaborated and currently under revision. This draft addresses both, the income regulation and visitor entering management.
NOTE: Followiong the 2014-PIR note, due to the importance of not only regulate the entry of visitors but also the income, finally the project will promote the update of the regulation for control and reinvestment of income.
5) 90% achieved: Regulatory guidelines for environmental standards and certification system for ecotourism designed. The strategy for implementing the certification system was stablished and the first pilot assessment was undertaken jointly with the Guatemala’s National Tourism Institute (INGUAT) and the Ministry of Culture and Sport (MICUDE).
More information about this achievement can be found in the Implementation Progress Section of this report.
6) Furthermore, the following management tools were designed and approved:
-Tourism in Protected Areas Potential Assessment Tool
- Guide for the Elaboration of Public Use Plans
- Committee for Tourism in Protected Areas (COTURAP) internal regulation was reformed

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 6.- Number of PAs implementing Public Use Plans (indicator for reformed Policy on Tourist Activities in PAs)

baseline.comment: Four (4)

actual.comment:
Overall Achievement: 65%
Progress in the design and approval of Public Use Plan:
1. Municipal Regional Park Astillero Municipal de San Marcos: 100% designed. Currently pending approval.
2. Municipal Regional Park Astillero Municipal I y II de San Pedro Sacatepéquez: 100% designed, Currently pending approval.
3. Municipal Regional Park Canjula, Tocapote, Los Maijones (Sibinal): 100% designed, Currently pending approval.
4. Municipal Regional Park Todos Santos Cuchumatan: 30% designed.
5. Permanent Ban Area Volcán de Chicabal: 0% designed. Consultant hired and works have already begun.
6. Corazon del Bosque: 0% designed.
7. Municipal Regional Park for Mirador Rey Tepepul: 100% designed but not yet submitted for approval. To achieve the approval of the Public Use Plan, it is previously necessary to achieve the registration of the area in the Guatemalan System of Protected Areas –SIGAP-. Although the project has supported the Municipality to resolve the problems faced about land tenure that historically did not allow the registration of the area, has not yet been included. Please find more information on this issue in the Development Objective Rating section of this report.
In addition, previous the design of Public Use Plans, it is necessary to design the Management Plan, which regulates the overall management of the protected area. The project is designing the Management Plan for the 7 pilot protected areas.
Progress in the design and approval of Management Plans:
1. Municipal Regional Park Astillero Municipal de San Marcos: 100% designed and approved.
2. Municipal Regional Park Astillero Municipal I y II de San Pedro Sacatepéquez: 100% designed. Currently pending approval.
3. Municipal Regional Park Canjula, Tocapote, Los Maijones (Sibinal): 100% designed. Currently pending approval.
4. Municipal Regional Park Todos Santos Cuchumatan:100% designed and approved.
5. Permanent Ban Area Volcan de Chicabal: 0% designed.
6. Corazon del Bosque: 60% designed. The activity has suffered repeated delays due to uncertainty over land tenure and administrator's internal organization problems. The land tenure uncertainty has been clarified and the project is currently supporting the community based organization which administrates de area in order to resolve internal organization challenges.
7. Municipal Regional Park for Mirador Rey Tepepul: 100% designed but not yet submitted for approval. Same situation than with the Public Use Plan.

baseline.comment: One (1): MRP Canjula Tocapote, Los Maijones

actual.comment:
Achievement: 0%
The business plans currently under construction include an analysis and identification of potential partners for the pilot areas. Once this activity has been finalized and the possible associates have been identified, the project will promote agreements aimed at the promotion of tourism.
However, progesses have already been made in order to prepare the 14 private initiatives supported through the program of incentives for the private sector “Programa Impulsa”. The project is working with them in order to adequate their touristic products to the needs of each area, facilitating future possible agreements.

Some of the activities carried out in order to achieve the target of this indicator are:
1) The implementation of the capacity building programme for protected areas' administrators.
The programme benefited a total, 124 people. The external evaluation concluded the following: "The program fulfilled its objective of increasing the technical capabilities of managers of protected areas, within both CONAP and its external partners. On the basis of these results, it can be concluded that giving full support to this training program will result in the improvement of the skills of CONAP technicians oriented towards the management of tourism in protected areas, thus contributing to the financial sustainability of the areas in accordance with the goal of preserving the biodiversity."
2) The launch of the "Diploma of Identification, Formulation, Evaluation and Presentation of Sustainable Touristic Projects" jointly organized by CONAP, INGUAT, the National Institute of Public Administration (INAP), the Secretariat of Planning and Programming of the Presidency (SEGEPLAN) and the National Agency for Public Private Partnership for the Development of Economic Infrastructure ( ANADIE). This 80 hour-course addressed to 30 public servants and seeks to train staff for the formulation of projects of touristic development in protected areas, from a perspective of sustainability, conservation and economic use. Especially relevant is the joint participation of several governmental institutions with the private sector, all which boost tourism as a crosscutting sector, whose development requires both a governmental strategy and a proper synergy with the private sector.
3) The implementation of the second edition of the training programme for CONAP Officials, which was carried out benefiting to 45 people (10 women and 35 men)

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 10.- Number of PAs in the Western Highlands established and registered in SIGAP

baseline.comment: Thirty-nine (39)

actual.comment:
Forty-three (43) Baseline + 4
Achievement: 200%
The following protected areas were registered during the current reporting period:
- Municipal Regional Park San Rafael Pie de la Cuesta, San Marcos (41.3 hectares)
- Municipal Regional Pack Piedras de Kab'tzin, Huehuetenango (304.3 hectares)
- Private Natural Reserve Monte de Oro (915.54 hectares)
The project has not directly taken action in order to the registration of these areas. However the activities aimed at strengthening the capacity of the CONAP's Regional Offices and in the deffinition of CONAP's internal processes, have positive effects in the promotion of new protected areas and in the promotion of tourism as a potential contributor to financial sustainability. The project financed a press tour to San Rafael Pie de la Cuesta in order to promote birdwatching tourism in this area where Quetzals are visible. This will greatly benefit the pilot areas in the proximities due to the attraction to visitors to the region.
In addition, the project is still supporting the registration of Rey Tepepul and Corazón del Bosque, two of the pilot areas of the project, which have presented historical problems related to the uncertainty of land tenure and internal organization. More information about this situation can be found in the Development Objective Rating Section of this report

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 11.- Number of PAs in the Western Highlands with monitoring, evaluation, and mitigation programs addressing impacts of ecotourism on ecologically sensitive areas

baseline.comment: Zero (0)

actual.comment:
90% achieved
The monitoring program was designed and implemented in the 7 pilot areas. Furthermore it includes a training program for municipality workers and CONAP´s regional officers in order to stablish the program in a ssutainable manner once the project hav fiished.
From this first pilot experience lessons have been learnt and adjustments will be undertaken in following editions. For this reason the achievement is considered 90% and not 100% although the seven areas already implement the monitoring, evaluation and mitigation program.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 12.- Change in the annual income generated in 22 PAs that have visitors

actual.comment: Improvement to be assessed through the Capacity Development Tracking Tool currently being undertaken in order to be ready before the Project Midterm Review.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: 13.- Number of PAs in the Western Highlands with a system of entrance fees and visitor services in operation

baseline.comment: Two (2): PBA Volcan and Laguna de Chicabal, and MRP Concepcion Chiquirichapa

actual.comment:
The total number of PAs with entrance fees in Western Highlands is 10. This represents an achievement of 125%.
Notice that from that total:
3 areas are part of the 7 pilot areas of the project
- Ban Area Volcan and Laguna Chicabal
- Corazon del Bosque
- Municipal Regional Park Canjula, Tocapote, Los Maijones are still operating
7 areas are other PAs in the Western Highlands which are not included as pilot area.
- Concepción Chiquirichapa (included in the baseline)
- Yul Ha Saj Ha´
- El Baul
- Cerro Mano de Leon (Cerro Sija)
- The entrance fee systems are currently operating in
- Astillero Municipal San Cristobal Cucho
- Refugio del Quetzal, San Rafael Pie de la cuesta, Volcan Tajumulco
In addition, in the Regional Park Todos Santos Cuchumatan, entrance fees are operating by 4 community-based tourism commissions. These groups are currently managing the tourism activity in the park but with a legal agreement with the Municipality, the legally stablished administrator of the area.
For the four pilot areas that have not implemented entrance fees yet: the project assisted in their calculation. Local governments received received the proposal as a very positive tool to increase income from tourism. However, local authorities stated that the upcoming elections do not provide a favourable political situation to implement these kind of measures.
The efforts in this direction will continue after the election period, when new new authorities have been elected.
As explained in other indicators, the project have not directly taken actions in order to implement entrance fees in areas out of the 7 pilot areas. However, the Capacity building programmes for CONAP's Regional Offices, and the promotion of tourism as financial tool for protected areas have positive effects also in other areas not included in those 7.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To strengthen land/forest management processes and biodiversity conservation in order to secure the flow of multiple ecosystems services while ensuring ecosystem resilience to climate change.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Number of hectares (ha) of humid forest under the CCB Standards in the western region (BD-2)

actual.comment:
* Progress of this target will be measured by mid-2016, before the midterm review, which is planned for later 2016.
* There are preliminary maps developed by the prtoject together with FUNDAECO and in consultation with local communities, indicating the priority areas for conservation of biodiversity under CCB Standars covering more than 1000 ha of humid forest.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description:
2. Area (ha) (by forest type) under best management practices in LULUCF*, including monitoring of C stocks (CCM-5)
*Conserve and enhance carbon stocks in selected forested areas.

baseline.comment:
? Dry forest: 620.1 ha
? Humid forest: 970.85 ha

target.comment:
? Dry forest: 1,500 ha
? Humid forest: 13,343 ha

actual.comment:
* Dry forest: 2000 ha. This was achieve with the joint work of the project with the Forest National Institute (INAB) as part the ongoing process to promote national incentives under the PINPEP modality.
* Humid forest: 50 ha. This was achieve with the work of FUNDAECO with the support of the project and in close collaboration and participation of the local communities and the National Forest Institute (INAB) as well as the support of the local authorities. The annual goal was not met due to two factors, the first is that the natural regeneration for this ecosystem is slow and takes more time. And secondly, for the lack of resources (economic and plants) to promote the natural regeneration and rehabilitation of the forest.
The expected target for 2015 was to have a first trial of the methods in the monitoring of C stocks, but this methodology still is under construction, as part of the REDD+ National Strategy.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
3. Area (ha) rehabilitated* (by forest type) (CCM-5)
*Reforestation with native species, natural regeneration, and sustainable agroforestry and silvopastoral systems.

baseline.comment:
? Dry forest: 79.15 ha
? Humid forest: 1,513.15 ha

target.comment:
? Dry forest: 3,000 ha
? Humid forest: 547 ha

actual.comment:
* Dry forest 200 ha. This was achieve with the work of the National Forest Institute (INAB) with the support of the project and the involvement of local authorities and other actors like farmers, non-governmental organizations and private companies, as part of their Corporate Social Responsibility Program.
* Humid forest: 50 ha. This was achieve with the work of FUNDAECO with the support of the project and in close collaboration and participation of the local communities and the National Forest Institute (INAB) as well as the support of the local authorities.
* The targets for 2015 are: At least 200 ha of Dry Forest rehabilitated and at least 1000 ha of Humid Montane Forest rehabilitated.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description:
4. Change in coverage (ha) and quality (rapid assessment method) of the forests in the dry areas
(LD-2)

actual.comment:
According to the latest map on forest coverage dynamics, the area still the same as baseline 6,838.47 ha
The map is generated by INAB, and since there is no update on the map, the official information is that the forest coverage is as stated at baseline.
The expected target for 2015 was focused on having a GIS monitoring tool and the capacity building of the municipalities, but this has not been reach mainly because the government has not agreed upon the GIS monitoring tool as well as the equipment needed for implementing the tool.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: 5. Avoided emissions (tCO2-e) from deforestation by forest type during a 5-year period (SFM/REDD-1)

baseline.comment:
? Dry forest: 0
? Humid forest: 0

target.comment:
? Dry forest: 413,114 tCO2-e
? Humid forest: 468,360 tCO2-e

actual.comment:
* Progress of this target will be measured by mid-2016, before the midterm review, which is planned for latter 2016.
* The C flows will be measure during 2016. In the framework of the construction of the National REDD+ Strategy, the Project is supporting the partners, for development the maps and tools for monitoring the C flows, in order to be able to measure it.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Regulatory and institutional framework integrates principles of sustainable forest management (SFM) and sustainable land management (SLM), and strengthens integrated environmental land management capacity.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 6. National policies incorporate SLM and SFM considerations

baseline.comment:
? Forest incentives program for small landowners
? Law for the Protection and Improvement of the Environment
? Forestry Policy

target.comment:
? National Action Program to Combat Desertification and Drought (PROANDYS) updated
? Agricultural Policy of Guatemala reformed

actual.comment:
* PROBOSQUE draft bill has been submitted to Congress. PROBOSQUE is a new draft bill that aims to replace the almost finished Program de Incentivos Forestales (PINFOR) program as well as to create a better system to incentivize the forest management and also, incorporates new forest ecosystems, that were not recognized in the past, subject to receive incentives. Altogether, the PORBOSQUE is using the forest as a basis to promote sustainable development in rural areas.
* For 2015 the target was to have a Policy on Land Degradation and the PROANDYS updated. At present, there is an update on all the biophysical and political information related to land degradation, desertification and drought. Also, the objective, strategic lines and principles are already drafted and accepted. The strategic plan with actions is under consultation as well as the actualization process of the PROANDYS.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 7. Number of national agencies working with inter-agency agreements that integrate principles of SFM and SLM.

target.comment: 5: MARN, MAGA, INAB, CONAP, and ANAM

actual.comment: * 4 agencies(Forest National Institute (INAB), Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock and Food (MAGA), Ministry of Environment and Natural Resources (MARN), National Council of Protected Areas (CONAP) and General Secretariat of Planning (SEGEPLAN)) includes principles of SLM and SFM in their policies, by having a common understanding of the concepts on SLM, SFM, climate change and Sustainable Use of Biodiversity. This was achieved by having consultation with legal representatives from the 4 agencies.

actual.comment: Progress of this target will be measured by mid-2016, before the midterm review, which is planned for latter 2016.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Pilot projects for SFM/REDD+ and SLM reduce land degradation, increase C stocks, and strengthen BD conservation in southeastern and western Guatemala.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 9. tCO2-e sequestered through dry forest rehabilitation

actual.comment: * Progress of this target will be measured by mid-2016, before the midterm review, which is planned for latter 2016. This will be implemented in close coordination with the National REDD+ Strategy.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 10. Number of ha protected through REDD+ practices during a 5-year period

actual.comment: Progress of this target will be measured at year 5 of the project, through the National Maps of forest cover and dynamics. For this, the project is supporting the national agencies (INAB, MARN, CONAP, MAGA) in the process to define the best areas to implement the REDD+ project altogether with the MRV System. That will help to ensure the best suitable areas of the regions, are considered under the REDD+ practices. At present there is a team of more than 8 technicians working full time to have all the geographical information in order to have all the information by the end of 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 11. Revenue/gross contributions (USD) through reduction of emissions under REDD+ during a 5-year period.

actual.comment: Progress of this target will be measured during year 5 of the project, with the projects to be presented by the communities. At present, the project is helping the national government to construct the National REDD+ Strategy and the MRV system. In this sense, it is expected by the end of 2015 to have a base information on the possible VCUs available for the each of the main region cover by the project, as well as some idea on the revenues that the communities might receive.

result.title: Objective
result.description: To promote the conservation and long-term sustainable use of marine and coastal biodiversity (BD) of global importance through effectively and equitably managed marine-coastal protected areas (MPAs), which will contribute to improving the economic welfare of the Guatemalan population.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Total area (in hectares [ha]) of marine and coastal areas under protection by MPAs in the Pacific

baseline.comment: -    7,042.44 ha

actual.comment: Agreements established with Protected Areas National Council (CONAP) for the development of 5 MPAs Technical Studies. Field work planned to start in October 2015. Progress of this target will be measure by mid-2017, before the midterm review, which is planned for latter 2017

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. Change in the management effectiveness of three (3) existing MPAs as measured through the METT scorecard

baseline.comment:

target.comment:

actual.comment: METT scorecards will be measured in 2017 before the midterm review, which is planned for latter 2017

indicator.description: 3. Change in the financial capacity of the MPAs according to that established through the total average score in the UNDP/GEF Sustainability Scorecard

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Strengthening the MPA legal, policy, and financial frameworks for the protection of marine-coastal BD and its sustainable use.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 4. Number of multiple-use MPAs declared and included in the SIGAP

baseline.comment: Three (3)

actual.comment: Agreements established with CONAP for the development of 5 MPAs Technical Studies. Field work planned to start in October 2015.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 5. Legal and regulatory framework facilitates the conservation and sustainable use of BD in the MPAs and buffer zones

baseline.comment:
? Regulations for Mangroves from the National Forest Institute (INAB, CONAP, and Bureau of State Land Reserves -OCRET)
?

target.comment:
? Regulatory reforms regarding the use and management of mangroves (INAB-CONAP-OCRET)
?

actual.comment:
Technical and legal opinions agreed and signed between INAB and CONAP for the regulatory reform regarding mangroves:
- Inter institutional legal opinion No. 02/2015 (June 18th)
- Joint technical opinion No. 01/2015 (June 17th)
Final proposal to be presented for approval to the board of directors of INAB before the end of 2015.
Regulations for Whale (Cetaceans) Watching were published in the official gazette on June 8th 2015. This support to CONAP will also include its dissemination with key local actors and guidelines to its effective implementation.
Note: A change of the indicator regarding the Law of Fishing and Aquaculture is requested with the support of the Technical Committee, aiming to a more viable initiative. The San José Canyon has been recognized by the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) as an Ecologically or Biologically Significant Marine Area (EBSA). Through a ministerial agreement it can be established as a ban area and/or breeding area of key species, particularly white shark and sailfish.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 6. Total annual budget from the central government (USD) assigned to the management of the MPAs and amount of financial resources received annually from private sources for the MPAs’ management

actual.comment:
Work plan agreed with OCRET and CONAP regarding coastal land rates and legal reforms for the financial sustainability of MPAs. Synergy with the BIOFIN project for viability of a financial mechanism. Progress of this target will be measure by mid-2017, before the midterm review, which is planned for latter 2017.
Note: A change of the target level is requested with the support of the Technical Committee. A more realistic amount could be a 25% increase equivalent to $841,658.10, instead of a 50% increase.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 7. Number of areas of biological importance declared by the Convention on Biological Diversity ()CBD) and regulated by a ministerial decree

baseline.comment: One area of biological importance already declared by the CBD (i.e, Cañon de San Jose)

target.comment: One area of biological importance already declared by CBD and regulated by Ministerial decree (i.e., Cañon de San Jose).

actual.comment: This is a new indicator. The Cañon de San Jose biological area will be regulated by ministerial decree in 2016. The San José Canyon has been recognized by the Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) as an Ecologically or Biologically Significant Marine Area (EBSA). The ministerial decree is needed to regulate the use white shark and sailfish, amongst other key species.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Strengthening the institutional and individual capacities for effective management of MPAs and the conservation and sustainable use of marine-coastal BD.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 8. Change in the capacity development indicators for MPAs management and the conservation and sustainable use of marine-coastal BD according to the total score of UNDP Capacity Development Scorecard (national and local government, private sector and civil society)

actual.comment:
In March 2015 a workshop on Mangrove Forest Management was held with a field work, at Manchón-Guamuchal; 24 technicians from INAB, CONAP and ICC (Private Institute on Climate Change) were trained to address mangrove restoration more effectively.
As a joint initiative with the ECOPLAN project from UNDP portfolio, a training program on “Land Use Planning in Coastal Marine Zones” was developed in Monterrico from March to June 2015. Capacities were strengthened for the following sectors/institutions, with a total of 20 technicians:
National government
- MARN (2)
- CONAP (3)
- INAB (1)
- DIPESCA (2)
- Secretary of Planning and Programming of the Presidency-SEGEPLAN (1)
Municipalities
- La Gomera (1)
- Iztapa (2)
- Taxisco (2)
- Pasaco (2)
- San José (1)
Civil society
- CECON (2)
- School of Biology (1)
Progress in this target will be measured through the Capacity Development Scorecards by 2017, before the midterm review, which is planned for latter 2017

actual.comment:
In May 2015 coordination started with DIPESCA-MAGA regarding monitoring and control. Several technical meetings and one workshop have resulted in consensus among staff from DIPESCA-MAGA (3), CONAP (1), INAB (1) and Ocean and Aquaculture Research Center CEMA-USAC (1) for monitoring formats that include threats to mangroves, fisheries and sea turtles.
Progress of this target will be measure by mid-2017, before the midterm review, which is planned for latter 2017

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 11. Increase in the number of monitoring, control, and surveillance plans and patrolling events

baseline.comment:
? Monitoring work plans: 0
? Patrolling events: 0

target.comment:
? Work plans: 5 (one/MPA/year during 5 years)
? Patrolling events: 120 per MPA (2/month/MPA during 5 years)

actual.comment:
One joint work plan (including methodology and timeframe) between DIPESCA-MAGA, CONAP and INAB has been built and from July to December it is expected to accomplish 5 patrolling events (1 x 5 MPA).
A monitoring program per MPA will be agreed as part of the Management Plans to be elaborated in 2016.

result.title: Outcome 3
result.description: Addressing threats from key sectors (fisheries, maritime ports/transportation, and urban development) in order to strengthen MPAs’ management and the conservation and sustainable use of marine-and coastal BD in the Pacific region of Guatemala.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 11. Coverage (ha) of key marine-coastal ecosystems in five (5) MPAs and their buffer zones

baseline.comment:
? Estuaries: 1,715 ha
? Coastal lagoons: 2,141 ha
? Herbaceous wetlands: 8,138 ha
? Sandy beaches: 21,135 ha
? Muddy beaches: 3,858 ha

actual.comment:
In order to maintain current levels of conservation and sustainable use of marine-coastal biodiversity, two initiatives requested by CONAP have been supported. Regulations for Whale Watching were published in the official gazette and the Hunting Calendar for the South Coast has been updated.
Progress of this target will be measure by mid-2017, before the midterm review, which is planned for latter 2017

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 12. Number of nurseries certified by CONAP for their good practices and compliance with the official Guidelines of the National Strategy for Sea Turtle Conservation in Guatemala.

baseline.comment: 0 nurseries

target.comment: Three (3) nurseries to be certified by CONAP: 1. Monterrico-CECON (Center for Conservation Studies)2. Hawaii-ARCAS (Wildlife Rescue and Conservation Association) 3. Sipacate-ICC (Private Institute for Climate Change)

actual.comment:
This is a new indicator.
A revision of the National Strategy for Sea Turtle Conservation in Guatemala was requested by CONAP. It was noticed that the Guidelines for release of sea turtle hatchlings are not being implemented satisfactory in the Pacific nurseries. This is why the nurseries need to be certified.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description:
13. Minimum sizes (cm) of select fish species in four (4) multiple-use MPAs and their buffer zones in conformance with FAO regulations[1]
[1] The regulation proposed by the FAO is aimed at the minimum sizes; in the case of fisheries maximum sizes are not considered, since the concern with the stocks of fish is that the organisms reach at least their initial reproduction size, which allows them to maintain stable populations. For other species there are no regulations regarding sizes.

baseline.comment:
Commercially important species:
? White Shrimp (Litopenaeus vannamei)
? Blue Shrimp (Penaeus stylirostris)
? Brown Shrimp (Farfantepenaeus.
californiensis)
? Hammerhead Shark (Sphyrna lewini)

target.comment:
Commercially important species:
? White Shrimp (Litopenaeus vannamei): 3 g or 6.6 cm.
? Blue Shrimp (Penaeus stylirostris): 3 g or 6.6 cm.
? Brown Shrimp (Farfantepenaeus californiensis): 3 g or 6.6 cm.
? Hammerhead Shark (Sphyrna lewini): 220 cm total length for females and 178 cm for males.

actual.comment:
Two initiatives leaded by DIPESCA-MAGA and CONAP focused on sharks (including Hammerhead Shark) and manta rays conservation started this year.
The first one is the characterization and assessment of state and the second one is a marketing chain and traceability system for these species. Both processes will support the country to accomplish acquired compromises as a CITES Contracting Party.
Compliance with the regulations of the General Law of Fishing and Aquaculture favors stable catches and sizes of four (4) selected fishing species.
Baseline: use of 600 meters gillnet, mesh size of ½ inches and 8 simultaneous gill nets (illegal fishing gear)
Target: use of 100 meters gillnet, 2.5 inches mesh size and 3 gillnets maximum (Article 50, Literal H of the normative of the General Law of Fishing and Aquaculture) contributes to sustainable use of:
1. Snapper (Lutjanus sp)
2. Yellowfin Snook (Centropomus robalito)
3. Mackerel (Scomberomorus sierra)
4. White Shrimp (Litopenaeus vannamei)

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 14. Change in average income received by fishermen implementing BD-friendly fishing practices.

actual.comment: This activity will start in 2016, once a characterization of artisan fisheries and the Business Plans are finalized.

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: 15. Coverage of mangroves in five (5) MPAs and their buffer zones

target.comment:
? 12,803.10 ha:
a. Sipacate – Naranjo National Park: 1,936.22 ha.
b. Monterrico Multiple-Use Natural Reserve: 2,664.32 ha.
c. La Chorrera Private Natural Reserve – RAMSAR site Manchón Guamuchal: 5,028.53 ha.
d. Hawaii Multiple-Use Area: 1,753.44 ha.
e. Las Lisas – La Barrona: 1,420.59 ha.

actual.comment: Databases and maps of mangrove coverage for the 5 MPAs will be obtained and/or updated as part of the Technical Studies elaboration.

indicator.description: 16. Number of hatchlings released by certified nurseries per reproductive period of the sea turtle Lepidochelys olivacea in the nesting beaches of the Pacific

actual.comment: This is a new indicator. Progress will be measured in 2016
